docs.title: 1. Strategic Purpose
docs.text:
This manual provides a rigorous, end-to-end governance and delivery framework for establishing temporary or permanent theatre venues in complex urban environments. It is specifically calibrated for railway-adjacent sites in Rotherhithe, Southeast London, but its methodology is applicable to any high-constraint capital arts project.

It transforms the "artistic vision" of a venue into a bankable, insurable, and legally compliant project structure. It is designed to satisfy the due diligence requirements of: * Statutory Bodies: Local Planning Authorities, Health & Safety Executive, Network Rail. * Funders: Arts Council England, NLHF, Social Investors. * Oversight: Boards of Trustees, Steering Groups, Insurers.

docs.title: 2. Core Methodology
docs.text: The manual enforces a Three-Phase Project Lifecycle (Discovery → Implementation → Closure) to control risk and capital exposure. * Discovery: Low-cost, high-intellect phase to validate feasibility before significant spend. * Implementation: Rigorous project management of the build, licensing, and operation. * Closure: Structured demobilisation to protect reputation and capture learning.

docs.title: 3. Risk and Governance Profile
docs.text: This is not merely a "how-to" guide; it is a risk management system. * Regulatory Compliance: Explicitly addresses CDM 2015, Licensing Act 2003, and GDPR. * Operational Safety: Mandates specific protocols for railway proximity (Asset Protection). * Financial Control: Requires sensitivity analysis and contingency planning (Low/Likely/High).

docs.text:

  • Project Managers/Producers: Use Part Two and Part Four (Templates) for daily execution.
  • Technical/Site Managers: Use Appendix 13.5 (Risk), 13.9 (H&S), and 13.11 (Rail) for operational safety.

Critical Note: This document constitutes guidance, not professional advice. All technical, legal, and safety decisions must be ratified by qualified professionals (Structural Engineers, Solicitors, Principal Designers) appointed to the specific project.

docs.title: Quick Start Playbook — First 7 Days (Director)
docs.text:
Strategic Purpose: Building Momentum While Establishing Foundations

The first week of any project sets the tone. Theatre professionals know this instinctively from rehearsals—the opening days establish working culture, trust, and momentum. Venue development is no different.

This playbook compresses critical Discovery Phase activities into seven focused days. It won't complete Discovery (that takes 3-6 months), but it will:

✔ Establish legal foundations (entity, insurance, basic contracts) ✔ Engage critical authorities (planning, Network Rail, TfL, fire service) ✔ Commission essential surveys (structural, topographical, contamination) ✔ Build stakeholder relationships (councillors, funders, community groups) ✔ Create financial reality check (indicative budget, funding gap analysis) ✔ Set governance framework (decision-making, risk management, communications)

Who Should Use This: Project directors, producers, or artistic leads initiating a venue development project. Assumes you have already identified a potential site and secured initial seed funding or board commitment to explore feasibility.

What Comes Next: After completing this playbook, transition to the 30/90 Day Action Playbook (Appendix 13.14) for comprehensive Discovery Phase completion.

Purpose: Maximise Impact in the Critical First Week

The first seven days set the tone for your entire project. This playbook ensures you make the essential decisions and initiate the critical actions that prevent delays later.

Golden Thread: Early actions in Week 1 determine your critical path timeline. Land registry delays, survey scheduling, and pre-app queues can each add 2-6 weeks. Front-load this work now.

**Critical Path (Red = Must Complete):**
- 🔴 Day 1: Land Registry search (blocks all site-specific work)
- 🔴 Day 2: Boundary plan creation (needed for pre-app and APA enquiry)
- 🔴 Day 2: TfL/Network Rail initial contact (long lead time for response)
- 🔴 Day 7: Board authorization (unlocks spending for Week 2+)

**Parallel Opportunities:**
- Days 3-4: Technical surveys can be quoted while awaiting regulatory responses
- Days 5-6: Financial modeling can proceed using assumptions pending survey data
- Days 6-7: Stakeholder outreach begins while technical work progresses

---

### Day-by-Day Action Checklist

#### **Day 1: Establish Legal Foundations**

**Morning (2-3 hours):**
- [ ] **Land Registry search** – Identify legal owner, boundaries, restrictive covenants
  - Visit: [gov.uk/search-property-information-land-registry](https://www.gov.uk/search-property-information-land-registry)
  - Cost: £3-7 per title; results within 24-48 hours
  - Save PDF to project folder: `/Legal/Land_Registry_[Site_Name]_[Date].pdf`

- [ ] **Note any restrictive covenants or easements** that could affect development
- [ ] **Create site boundary plan** (redline drawing showing your proposed use area)
  - Use Google Maps satellite view as base; mark boundaries in red
  - This is critical for all subsequent applications

**Afternoon (2-3 hours):**
- [ ] **Initial site photos** – Photograph site from multiple angles, include:
  - Boundaries and access points
  - Railway boundary (if adjacent)
  - Neighboring properties
  - Existing structures or constraints
  - Date-stamp all images (camera metadata or photo editing tool)

- [ ] **Create project folder structure:**
  ```text
  [Project_Name]/
  ├── Legal/
  ├── Technical_Surveys/
  ├── Planning_Building_Control/
  ├── Health_Safety/
  ├── Financial/
  ├── Community_Engagement/
  └── Communications/
  ```

**Output:** Land ownership confirmed, site documented, folder structure ready.

---

#### **Day 2: Engage Statutory Authorities**

**Morning (3-4 hours):**
- [ ] **Contact TfL Property / Network Rail Asset Protection** (if railway-adjacent)
  - Email template: [Appendix 13.11](#appendix-13-11) APA Enquiry Template
  - Subject: "Initial Enquiry: Proposed Temporary Venue at [Site Name]"
  - Attach: Site photos, redline boundary plan
  - Log: Expected response time 5-10 working days

- [ ] **Submit Southwark pre-application enquiry request**
  - Portal: [planning.southwark.gov.uk](https://planning.southwark.gov.uk)
  - Fee: Typically £150-300 for minor development
  - Attach: Site plan, brief project description (1 page)
  - Timeline: Response typically 4-6 weeks

**Afternoon (2-3 hours):**
- [ ] **Research Conservation Area / Listed Building constraints**
  - Check Southwark planning portal for designations
  - If Conservation Area, note Article 4 Directions
  - If within 10m of railway, note this for Asset Protection team

- [ ] **Create stakeholder contact matrix** (Excel/Google Sheets):

| Stakeholder | Contact Name | Email | Phone | Status | Notes |
|:------------|:-------------|:------|:------|:-------|:------|
| TfL Property | [TBC] | property@tfl.gov.uk | | Enquiry sent [date] | |
| Network Rail AP | [TBC] | [from website] | 03457 11 41 41 | Enquiry sent [date] | |
| Southwark Planning | [TBC] | | 020 7525 5000 | Pre-app submitted [date] | |

**Output:** Statutory consultations initiated; response timelines logged.

---

#### **Day 3: Commission Critical Surveys**

**Morning (2-3 hours):**
- [ ] **Identify and contact survey providers:**
  - **Ground Penetrating Radar (GPR)** – Essential for railway-adjacent sites
    - Detects buried structures, utilities, voids
    - Typical cost: £800-2,000
    - Timeline: 1-2 weeks to schedule, 1 week for report

  - **Topographical survey** – Accurate site levels for design
    - Typical cost: £500-1,500
    - Timeline: 1-2 weeks

  - Request quotes from 2-3 providers; compare price and availability

- [ ] **Brief surveyors on project requirements:**
  - Emphasize railway proximity (if applicable)
  - Request CAD format outputs for architect use
  - Confirm insurance and accreditation

**Afternoon (2-3 hours):**
- [ ] **Request early Quantity Surveyor (QS) budget estimate**
  - Brief: "Temporary outdoor theatre, [capacity], [duration], [site constraints]"
  - Request: High-level cost estimate (±30% accuracy acceptable at this stage)
  - Purpose: Reality-check budget assumptions before deeper investment
  - See [Appendix 13.18](#appendix-13-18) for budget line items to include in brief

- [ ] **Create survey tracker:**

| Survey Type | Provider | Quote | Scheduled | Report Due | Status |
|:------------|:---------|------:|:---------:|:----------:|:-------|
| GPR | [Company] | £1,200 | [Date] | [Date] | Quoted |
| Topographical | [Company] | £850 | [Date] | [Date] | Quoted |

**Output:** Surveys commissioned; budget reality-check initiated.

---

#### **Day 4: Establish Health & Safety Framework**

**Morning (2-3 hours):**
- [ ] **Appoint interim H&S consultant** (part-time, Discovery phase only)
  - Essential competencies: CDM 2015 knowledge, railway safety (if applicable)
  - Deliverables: Initial risk assessment, H&S file structure, Principal Designer recommendation
  - Budget: £1,500-3,000 for Discovery phase support

- [ ] **Brief H&S consultant on project:**
  - Site constraints (railway, access, ground conditions)
  - Timeline and anticipated construction methods
  - Request: Preliminary risk identification and CDM role assignment plan

**Afternoon (2-3 hours):**
- [ ] **Identify and contact Principal Designer candidates**
  - Must have: Chartered professional status (RIBA/IStructE), CDM experience, railway site experience (if applicable)
  - Request: CV, relevant project examples, day-rate
  - Timeline: Appoint before any design work commences

- [ ] **Create H&S file structure:**
  ```
  Health_Safety/
  ├── Risk_Register_[Version].xlsx
  ├── CDM_Roles_Responsibilities.pdf
  ├── Pre_Construction_Information/
  └── Method_Statements_RAMS/
  ```

**Output:** H&S governance initiated; competent professionals engaged.

---

#### **Day 5: Stakeholder Mapping & Engagement Planning**

**Morning (3-4 hours):**
- [ ] **Create comprehensive stakeholder map** – Identify all parties who can:
  - **Block** the project (regulators, landowner, Network Rail)
  - **Support** the project (funders, community groups, councillors)
  - **Benefit** from the project (local businesses, residents, artists)
  - **Influence** the project (media, cultural organizations, opinion leaders)

**Stakeholder Power/Interest Matrix**
HIGH POWER ↑ │ ┌─────────────────────────┼─────────────────────────┐ │ KEEP SATISFIED │ MANAGE CLOSELY │ │ (Inform & Consult) │ (Active Partnership) │ │ │ │ LOW │ • Network Rail AP │ • TfL Property │ HIGH INTEREST│ • HSE │ • Southwark Planning │ INTEREST ←────┤ • Building Control │ • Arts Council England │────→ │ • Fire Service │ • Major Funders │ │ • Thames Water │ • Ward Councillors │ │ │ • Principal Designer │ │ │ • Principal Contractor │ ├─────────────────────────┼─────────────────────────┤ │ MONITOR │ KEEP INFORMED │ │ (Minimal Effort) │ (Regular Updates) │ │ │ │ │ • General Public │ • Rotherhithe Forum │ │ • Wider Arts Sector │ • Local Businesses │ │ • Trade Associations │ • Community Groups │ │ • Academic Observers │ • Local Press │ │ │ • Neighbouring Residents│ │ │ • Brunel Museum │ └─────────────────────────┼─────────────────────────┘ │ ↓ LOW POWER ```

Engagement Strategy by Quadrant:

Quadrant Strategy Frequency Method Key Principle Manage Closely(High Power, High Interest) Active partnership; co-create solutions; regular two-way dialogue Weekly-Monthly Face-to-face meetings, working groups, joint planning "Nothing about us without us" Keep Satisfied(High Power, Low Interest) Meet their requirements; avoid surprising them; formal compliance Quarterly or as required Formal notifications, compliance reports "Stay on their radar positively" Keep Informed(Low Power, High Interest) Provide information; invite participation; acknowledge concerns Monthly Newsletters, open meetings, social media "Build supporters and advocates" Monitor(Low Power, Low Interest) General communications; minimal active effort Ad-hoc Website, public notices, press releases "Inform but don't burden"

Stakeholder Movement: Positions can shift! A community group (Keep Informed) can move to Manage Closely if they mobilize opposition. Monitor the matrix monthly.

  • Identify ward councillor for the site:
  • Visit Southwark Council website → "Find my councillor"
  • Email to arrange introductory meeting (Week 2 target)

Afternoon (2 hours): - [ ] Draft initial project description (1 page) for stakeholder communications: - Project vision (2-3 sentences) - Proposed location and duration - Community benefits - Timeline overview - Contact details

  • Schedule pre-app submission completion for Week 3-4:
  • Check what's needed: site plan ✓, project description ✓, fee ✓
  • Confirm all elements ready

Output: Stakeholder engagement strategy mapped; key contacts identified.

docs.title: Day 6: Financial Framework & Budget Reality Check
docs.text:
Morning (3 hours): - [ ] Build indicative budget spreadsheet using Appendix 13.18 template: - List all cost categories (structural, temporary power, canopies, professional fees, etc.) - Input: Low / Likely / High estimates for each - Calculate total range - Add 15-20% contingency

  • Identify primary cost drivers – Typically:
  • Foundations (especially if piling required)
  • Asset Protection Agreement compliance (railway sites)
  • Professional fees (engineers, H&S, planning consultant)

  • Temporary infrastructure (power, toilets, fencing)

  • Funding gap analysis:

  • Total likely cost: £_
  • Confirmed funding: £_
  • Gap: £_

Afternoon (2 hours): - [ ] Research funding sources (initial scan): - Arts Council England: artscouncil.org.uk – check current open rounds - National Lottery Heritage Fund (if heritage angle): heritagefund.org.uk - Southwark Council cultural grants: contact culture@southwark.gov.uk - Local trusts and foundations

  • Note application deadlines and lead times – Most funders require 3-6 months lead time

Output: Realistic budget framework; funding gap quantified; initial funding research complete.

docs.title: Day 7: Governance & Communication
docs.text:
Morning (2-3 hours): - [ ] Prepare Board briefing email summarizing Week 1 progress:

Subject: [Project Name] – Week 1 Progress & Key Decisions Required

Content: - Land ownership confirmed: [Yes/No/Complications] - Statutory consultations initiated: [List] - Surveys commissioned: [List with timelines] - Budget reality check: [Range] - Funding gap: [Amount] - Decisions needed in Week 2: - Approve Discovery Phase budget (£[amount]) - Authorize Principal Designer appointment - Endorse stakeholder engagement approach

Attachments: - Site photos - Redline boundary plan - Initial budget spreadsheet - Stakeholder map

  • Schedule Board meeting / call for Week 2 to review findings and authorize next phase

Afternoon (2 hours): - [ ] Create Week 2-4 action plan: - Pre-app submission finalization (Week 3) - Survey report reviews (Week 3-4) - Community engagement initiation (Week 3) - Principal Designer appointment (Week 2) - H&S initial risk assessment (Week 3)

  • Set up project management tools:
  • Shared cloud folder (Google Drive / Dropbox)
  • Communication platform (Slack / Teams / email group)
  • Task tracker (Trello / Asana / Excel)

Output: Governance loop closed; Week 2 priorities clear; team aligned.

docs.title: Week 1 Success Criteria
docs.text:
✅ Legal foundation established – Land ownership confirmed, site documented ✅ Statutory engagement initiated – TfL/Network Rail contacted, pre-app submitted ✅ Technical surveys commissioned – GPR, topo, budget estimate underway ✅ H&S framework started – Consultant appointed, Principal Designer identified ✅ Stakeholders mapped – Engagement strategy clear ✅ Financial reality check complete – Budget range, funding gap quantified ✅ Governance aligned – Board briefed, Week 2 decisions framed

If you've completed 80%+ of these actions in Week 1, you're on track for a successful Discovery Phase.

docs.title: Glossary of Terms
docs.text:
Technical and Legal Terms Explained

Acoustic Treatment: Materials or design features that control sound (absorption, diffusion, reflection) to improve speech intelligibility or musical quality.

Asset Protection Agreement: Formal contract with Network Rail governing any construction or activity within 10m of operational railway, ensuring works do not compromise safety.

Bearing Capacity: Maximum load that ground can support without failure; determined by geotechnical survey; critical for foundation design.

Building Regulations: UK statutory requirements for building design and construction covering structural integrity, fire safety, accessibility, energy efficiency; enforced by local authority Building Control.

Community Interest Company (CIC): UK legal structure for social enterprises; limited company with asset lock preventing private profit extraction; lighter regulation than charity.

Completion Certificate: Official document from Building Control confirming building complies with Building Regulations; legally required before occupation.

Conservation Area: Geographic zone designated for special architectural or historic character; additional planning controls apply to preserve character.

Construction Phase Plan: Document required under CDM Regulations detailing how construction will be safely executed, including risk assessments and method statements.

Contingency (Budget): Additional funds (typically 10-20% of project cost) held in reserve for unforeseen costs or variations.

Critical Path: Sequence of project tasks that determines minimum duration; any delay to critical path tasks delays entire project.

Decibel (dB): Unit measuring sound intensity; logarithmic scale (80dB is 10× louder than 70dB, not 10% louder); UK planning typically uses dB(A) (A-weighted, approximating human hearing).

Demountable: Designed to be assembled and disassembled without destruction; allows reuse or relocation; critical for "temporary" classification.

Disclosure and Barring Service (DBS): UK system for checking criminal records; required for anyone working with children or vulnerable adults; three levels (Basic, Standard, Enhanced).

Environmental Impact Assessment (EIA): Formal assessment of project's environmental effects; required for certain large developments; unlikely for small theatre projects unless in sensitive location.

Feasibility Study: Preliminary investigation assessing whether project is viable (technically, financially, legally); output is recommendation to proceed or not.

Float (Project Management): Amount of time a task can delay without affecting overall project completion; tasks with zero float are on critical path.

F10 Notification: Form submitted to Health & Safety Executive notifying them of construction project meeting certain thresholds (CDM Regulations requirement).

Go/No-Go Decision: Formal decision point (typically end of Discovery Phase) where project sponsor decides whether to commit to Implementation based on evidence gathered.

Ground Penetrating Radar (GPR): Non-invasive survey technique using radio waves to detect buried objects (utilities, foundations); supplements statutory utility records.

Health and Safety File: Document required under CDM Regulations providing information about building/structure for future maintenance, alteration, or demolition; given to client at project completion.

Imposed Load: Weight of movable items (people, furniture, equipment) on structure; distinct from dead load (weight of structure itself); UK Building Regulations specify minimum imposed loads for different occupancies.

Leq (Equivalent Continuous Sound Level): Average sound level over a time period; commonly used metric in noise assessments; e.g., "Leq 60dB(A) over 1 hour" means average noise was 60 decibels.

Licensable Activities: Activities requiring a licence under the Licensing Act 2003: sale of alcohol, regulated entertainment, late-night refreshment.

Listed Building: Structure of special architectural or historic interest; protected by law; alterations require Listed Building Consent; three grades (I, II*, II) reflecting significance.

Lmax: Maximum instantaneous sound level during measurement period; used alongside Leq to show peak noise events (e.g., train pass-by).

Meanwhile Use: Temporary occupation of land or building awaiting long-term use; often low-rent arrangements benefiting both owner (property maintained, rates reduced) and occupier (affordable space).

Means of Escape: Routes people can use to exit building/venue in emergency; Building Regulations specify maximum travel distances and minimum widths.

Memorandum of Understanding (MoU): Non-binding agreement outlining terms of collaboration; lighter than formal contract; common in early partnerships.

Piled Foundation: Deep foundation using driven or drilled piles (columns) to transfer load to stable ground below weak surface soils; more expensive than shallow foundations but sometimes necessary.

Premises Licence: Licence authorising specific premises to conduct licensable activities; granted by local authority licensing committee; valid indefinitely (subject to conditions compliance).

Pre-Application Consultation (Pre-App): Optional service where developer pays council planning department for informal advice before submitting formal application; strongly recommended for complex projects.

Principal Contractor: Role under CDM Regulations; contractor responsible for site safety during construction, coordinating all trades and workers.

Principal Designer: Role under CDM Regulations; designer (usually architect or engineer) responsible for coordinating design-stage health and safety, preparing pre-construction information.

Rateable Value: Assessed rental value of property used to calculate business rates (property tax); also determines some fee scales (e.g., licensing fees).

Registered Proprietor: Legal owner of land as shown on Land Registry title; may be freehold owner or leaseholder.

Restrictive Covenant: Legal restriction on land use recorded on title register; e.g., "no building over two storeys" or "maintain access for neighbouring property."

Risk Score: Product of likelihood and impact in risk assessment; used to prioritise risks (higher score = more attention needed).

Scaffold (Tube and Fitting): Modular temporary structure using standard steel tubes connected with couplers; versatile and widely used in construction and events.

Scheduled Monument: Archaeological site protected under Ancient Monuments Act; requires Scheduled Monument Consent for any work; Brunel Tunnel infrastructure has this status.

Section 106 Agreement: Legal agreement attached to planning permission requiring developer to provide community benefits or mitigate impacts; named after Section 106 of Town and Country Planning Act 1990.

Social Value: Non-financial benefit to society (employment, skills, health, environment); increasingly factored into funding decisions and procurement.

Sole Plate (Scaffold): Timber plank placed under scaffold base plate to distribute load across wider area; prevents sinking into soft ground.

Structural Calculations: Engineering analysis proving structure can safely carry loads; required by Building Control; must be certified by Chartered Structural Engineer.

Sui Generis: Latin: "of its own kind"; planning use class for unique uses not fitting standard categories; often applied to theatres, venues, etc.

Temporary Event Notice (TEN): Permit allowing licensable activities for up to 168 hours (7 days) for up to 499 people; simpler and cheaper than Premises Licence but limited number per year.

Topographical Survey: Precise measurement of site levels and features; produces accurate drawings used for design and planning applications; conducted by Chartered Land Surveyor.

Travel Distance: Distance person must travel from any point in building to reach place of safety; Building Regulations set maximum travel distances based on occupancy and fire risk.

Use Class: Planning categorization of land/building use; determines whether planning permission needed for change of use; UK system revised in 2020.

docs.title: 1. Immediate Steps (Discovery Phase)
docs.text:
• Identify the rail asset owner (Network Rail or TfL) and log the asset id and map reference.
  • Conduct a site walk with photographs establishing the rail boundary and distance to live lines; create a red-line site plan showing any interfaces with track infrastructure.

  • Contact Asset Protection and request initial guidance; record the Asset Protection contact details and ticket number.

  • Documents you must have before any works near track are permitted

  • Site plan showing existing and proposed works (CAD / pdf)
  • Temporary works drawings (scaffold, platforms, gantries) and structural calculations signed by a Chartered Structural Engineer
  • Method Statements and the specific RAMS for works near the live line
  • Construction Phase Plan and Health & Safety File (CDM) for contractors
  • Proof of contractor competence: training, accreditation, and insurance (indemnity and public liability)
  • Communication plan showing shift handovers, lookouts, and safe access routes

  • Signing/lighting plan for any works requiring night operations near the line

  • Asset Protection Agreement (APA) and timelines

  • Early engagement: contact Network Rail/TfL as soon as Discovery confirms proximity to track (Week 1)
  • Initial technical call: 2–6 weeks to receive guidance and an initial site meeting request
  • APA drafting/negotiation: typical duration 6–12 weeks depending on complexity; factor into your critical path

  • APA approvals: attach copies to pre-construction information and supply to Principal Designer and Principal Contractor

  • Typical protective measures required by the rail asset owner

  • Fencing and exclusion zones (temporary palisade or Heras with buttresses)
  • Skeletal protection (catch-fencing or sacrificial sheeting) for dropped objects
  • Temporary access routes with separation from track (signage and secure gates)
  • Trained lookouts for works adjacent to live lines and contractor-specific safety briefings

  • Protection of temporary cabling and servicing to prevent trespass or track contamination

  • H&S Monitoring schedule (rail-adjacent enhancements)

  • Daily: site manager completes the daily H&S checklist (Appendix 13.9) with additional check: fencing integrity at rail boundary, lookouts in place, and radio comms tested.
  • Weekly: Principal Contractor runs a weekly site safety inspection, documents any non-conformances, and updates the H&S file.
  • Monthly: Monthly review by the client/Producer of all incidents and the risk register; update Asset Protection liaison point.

  • Post-incident: Immediate suspension and formal post-incident review by the Principal Designer, H&S lead and Asset Protection before restart.

  • Example Incident Protocol (rail adjacent)

  • Immediately stop works and secure area; confirm safety of any person involved
  • Call Network Rail emergency number for asset incidents and follow the Asset Protection guidance
  • Activate the site Emergency Action Plan including first-aider and site manager confirmation

  • Record incident, collect witness statements, and keep the area preserved for asset inspection

  • Who signs-off what and when

  • Principal Designer to review all temporary works and sign RAMS pre-construction
  • Principal Contractor as lead on site safety; responsible for daily RAMS adherence

  • Asset Protection: final sign-off (in writing) before any intrusive works

  • Sample 'Asset Protection' enquiry template (discover step)

    Dear [Asset Protection Team],

    We are planning a temporary venue at [Site Name and Address] which sits adjacent to Network Rail/TfL infrastructure. We request an initial technical meeting to discuss required asset protection, APA timelines, and any constraints on delivery (e.g., possessions, times for deliveries at night). Please find attached a site plan, photos, and a proposed scope of works.

    Contact: [Name, role, phone, email]

    Please confirm the preferred next steps and any fee or APA process requirements.

See the site toolkit for downloadable templates: toolkit/apa-enquiry-template-full.md and toolkit/apa-clause-sample.md.

docs.title: Appendix 13.13 – Accessibility & Inclusion Checklist
docs.text:
[GOVERNANCE NOTE: BEYOND COMPLIANCE] Accessibility is not just about ramps; it is about welcome. Meeting the Equality Act is the minimum legal standard, not the target. Risk: Exclusionary practices can lead to reputational damage and loss of public funding.

This checklist is to ensure the venue meets Equality Act and good practice expectations. It is not a substitute for detailed design by an accessibility consultant, but it is a practical working template for the delivery team.

  1. Access routes and entrances
  2. Clear step-free route to an accessible entrance with ramp gradient <1:12 where required

  3. Arrival signage and pick-up/drop-off space considered for accessible transport

  4. Internal circulation

  5. Minimum clear width of 900mm on routes used by audiences/staff
  6. Tactile and high-contrast signage on level changes and exits

  7. Escape routes designed with refuges where stairs are present

  8. Seating and viewing

  9. Minimum accessible platform (wheelchair) positions with companion seats for each block of audience

  10. Clear sightlines from accessible positions

  11. Ticketing and FOH

  12. Accessible booking option online and via phone
  13. Front-of-house training to support disabled people

  14. Quiet/sensory rooms for patrons with sensory needs

  15. Facilities

  16. At least one accessible toilet with adult-sized changing table or tracking hoist if required by the audience profile

  17. Communications

  18. Hearing loop or infra-red system where possible; clear pre-performance PA messages for audiences with sensory impairment

  19. Provide a 'relaxed performance' variant where appropriate and document adjustments

  20. Monitoring and reporting

  21. Include an Accessibility section in the daily checklist and post-show monitoring
  22. Engage local access groups during Discovery and record accessibility requirements in the project Health & Safety plan

docs.title: Stewarding, FOH & Minimum Ratios
docs.text:
• Recommended stewarding ratio for unseated/outdoor events: 1 steward per 50 audience members for standard sites; for rail adjacent or high-risk sites use 1 steward per 30.
  • Minimum of one trained first-aider on site and one steward trained in basic evacuation and fire marshal duties per performance.
  • All stewards should receive a pre-shift briefing covering crowd dynamics, evacuation routes, railway boundary protocols, and communications plan.
  • For rail-adjacent sites, bolstered stewarding at vulnerable touchpoints (gates, track-facing boundaries) is recommended—consider dedicated track-boundary watchers during set-up/pack-down.

docs.title: 13.6 Audience Survey Template
docs.text:
[GOVERNANCE NOTE: DATA AS ASSET] Audience data is your most valuable long-term asset. Without it, you cannot prove demand to future funders. Compliance: You must have a lawful basis for collecting this data (see Appendix 13.12).

Purpose: Gather quantitative and qualitative feedback from audiences to support evaluation, funder reporting, and future programming decisions.

When to Use: Distribute surveys at the end of each performance or via email post-event. Aim for a 30-40% response rate by incentivising completion (e.g., prize draw entry).

Key Metrics to Capture: - Demographic data (age, postcode, ethnicity—optional) - How they heard about the event - Overall satisfaction rating - Likelihood to recommend (Net Promoter Score) - What worked well / what could improve - Interest in future events

Data Protection Note: Ensure survey includes privacy notice and GDPR-compliant data handling. See Appendix 13.12 for privacy notice template.

docs.title: Appendix 13.18 — Sample Budget Line Items & Sensitivity (Example)
docs.text:
[GOVERNANCE NOTE: OPTIMISM BIAS] Most theatre projects go over budget because they underestimate complexity. This template forces you to confront the "High Case" scenario. Rule of Thumb: If you cannot afford the "Likely" case + 15% contingency, you do not have a viable project.

Purpose: Build Realistic Financial Expectations

Use this sample budgeting structure during Discovery to challenge assumptions and build a robust capital plan. Replace sample numbers with your own quotes and update with supplier tender figures in Implementation.

Golden Thread: The difference between Low and High scenarios often represents the difference between project success and failure. Model all three scenarios; secure funding for the Likely case; maintain contingency for the High case.

Key Insights for Budget Management:

Cost Category Low (£) Likely (£) High (£) Sensitivity Risk Mitigation Priority Structural Works 12,000 25,000 50,000 HIGHEST 🔴 Obtain fixed-price quotes early; conduct GPR survey before committing Professional Fees 5,000 12,000 30,000 HIGH 🟠 Scope services clearly; consider fixed-fee vs hourly; APA costs variable Canopies & Kit 8,000 12,000 20,000 MEDIUM 🟡 Reusable kit reduces cost; weather rating affects price Temporary Power 2,000 4,000 7,000 MEDIUM 🟡 Solar option cheaper; generator requires fuel budget Acoustic/Equipment 6,000 10,000 16,000 MEDIUM 🟡 Hire vs buy decision; technical spec affects price Steward & License 3,000 6,000 10,000 LOW 🟢 Volunteers reduce cost; licensing fees are fixed

Budget Control Strategy:

  1. Secure structural costs first - Biggest impact; hardest to reduce mid-project
  2. Get multiple professional fee quotes - Wide variation between providers
  3. Lock in long-lead items early - Canopies, generators have 6-8 week lead times
  4. Maintain 15-20% contingency - Based on High case scenario for top 3 cost drivers
  5. Monitor actuals weekly - Variance >10% on high-sensitivity items triggers review

Funding Strategy Implication: Secure funding for Likely case + 15% contingency. If High case materializes on multiple items simultaneously, you may need to: - Activate reserve funding sources - Reduce scope (shorter run, smaller capacity) - Seek additional grants (requires 3-6 month lead time)

docs.title: Final Thoughts for the Theatre Director
docs.text:
You've Reached the End—But This Is Just the Beginning

[INFERRED JUDGEMENT] If you've read this far, you now possess something rare: a comprehensive understanding of what it truly takes to create a theatre venue in one of the UK's most challenging urban environments. This knowledge transforms aspiration into achievable reality.

The Eight Pillars of Success

Creating a temporary theatre project—especially on challenging sites like railway-adjacent land—requires mastery of eight interconnected disciplines:

  1. Rigorous planning – no shortcuts; every permission, every survey, every stakeholder matters.
  2. Patience – regulatory processes take longer than you hope; build buffers.
  3. Flexibility – you'll face surprises; adapt without compromising safety or vision.
  4. Partnerships – no one succeeds alone; invest in relationships.
  5. Financial realism – costs always exceed first estimates; model conservatively.
  6. Community focus – this is for Rotherhithe; keep local benefit at the centre.
  7. Professional support – hire experts (engineers, lawyers, consultants); it's false economy to DIY everything.
  8. Artistic courage – don't lose sight of why you're doing this; let creativity lead.

  • You can secure £100k-£150k for the Brunel Road temporary project (or £2m-£4m for the Pumphouse permanent venue).
  • You have strong artistic vision that responds to site constraints.
  • You're willing to engage the community authentically (not just consultation box-ticking).
  • You can build a skilled, committed team (even if small).
  • You have organisational resilience (CIC structure, competent governance).

  • You're unwilling to invest in professional advice.
  • You see the community as an obstacle rather than a partner.

  • You cannot comply with safety requirements (non-negotiable near railway).

This manual is grounded in professional project management methodology, specifically the three-phase project lifecycle: Discovery → Implementation → Closure. Bridging Artistic Process and Delivery Rigour

Epistemic Note: The following analysis is derived from common failure modes observed in UK cultural infrastructure projects (2015-2025).

Theatre-makers often approach projects with artistic flexibility: "Let's start rehearsing and see what emerges." This works beautifully for devised performance but can be disastrous for venue development.

Building a venue—even a temporary one—involves: - Legal permissions that take months and cannot be rushed - Financial commitments that cannot be easily reversed - Safety obligations that are non-negotiable - Multiple stakeholders whose trust, once lost, is hard to regain

The project lifecycle provides discipline without stifling creativity. It asks you to pause at key moments (end of Discovery, before major spend in Implementation) and consciously decide: "Do we have enough information? Are we ready? Should we proceed?"

docs.title: Appendix 13.14 — Director's 30 / 90 Day Action Playbook
docs.text:
[GOVERNANCE NOTE: EXECUTIVE ACCOUNTABILITY] The Director is responsible for the pace and momentum of the project. Delay is the enemy of temporary projects. Focus: Do not get lost in artistic detail before the site is secured.

30 Day (Discovery Fast Start) - Week 1: Land registry check; initial site reconnaissance; contact TfL/Network Rail & Southwark pre-app; basic budget check (ordnance survey, estimated costs) - Week 2: Commission topographical survey and GPR; brief a heritage/spec survey if in conservation area; liaise with neighbours; begin community mapping - Week 3–4: Pre-app submission to Southwark; appoint a consultant team for costing (QS), H&S, and accessibility if affordable; apply for small feasibility grants if needed

90 Day (Discovery completion) - Month 2: Complete feasibility: high-level capital & operating model, funding strategy, initial community consultation - Month 3: Decision: Go/No-Go based on feasibility; board expectation to sign off Discovery outputs and accept risk register

This Playbook checklist is intended for the non-technical Director to help make urgent, high-leverage decisions in a timeline sensitive environment.

docs.title: Appendix 13.22 — Sample Data Processing Clauses (Non-legal; to be reviewed)
docs.text: Insert into simple contractor or supplier contracts where data is processed (e.g., box office / ticketing) - Data Processing: Supplier processes personal data as a processor on behalf of the Project. - Purpose: Supplier will process data only for ticketing and customer-service purposes. - Security: Supplier to keep data encrypted in transit and at rest, maintain MFA for admin accounts, and use secure backups. - Sub-processors: Supplier to notify Project of new sub-processors with an opt-out clause. - Deletion: Supplier will return or delete personal data upon contract termination, except for financial records kept for 7 years for audit. - Breach notification: Supplier will notify the Project within 24 hours of confirming a reportable actual breach.

docs.title: 13.8 Funder Report Template
docs.text:
Strategic Context: Funders as Partners, Not Just Paymasters

[GOOD PRACTICE] Funder reporting is often seen as an administrative burden. Reframe it: this is your opportunity to demonstrate impact, build trust, and strengthen relationships for future applications. A well-crafted funder report tells your project's story with evidence, honesty, and learning.

docs.title: Appendix 13.12 — Data Protection (GDPR) & Privacy Pack
docs.text:
[GOVERNANCE NOTE: LEGAL COMPLIANCE] Data Protection is not an administrative task; it is a statutory obligation. Failure to comply with the UK GDPR and Data Protection Act 2018 can result in: - Fines of up to £17.5m or 4% of global turnover. - Reputational destruction (loss of trust from audience and funders). - Personal liability for Directors in cases of negligence.

The "Golden Rule": If you do not need the data, do not collect it. If you collect it, you must protect it.

This section summarises the minimum steps required to comply with data protection obligations relevant to ticketing, volunteers, staff and incident records.

  1. Roles and responsibilities
  2. Data Controller: the legal organisation that holds ticket sales and fundraising income (usually the CIC or charity)

  3. Data Processor(s): box office provider, online ticketing service, volunteer management platform

  4. Minimum documentation

  5. Data Processing Agreement (DPA) with any ticketing or box-office provider
  6. Privacy Notice (public-facing) that warns what data you collect, why, retention and how to exercise rights
  7. Data Retention Schedule: ticketing records for financial audit – 7 years (standard for accounts); incident logs for 3–6 years depending on legal/regulatory guidance

  8. Data breach response plan with named Data Protection Lead, steps to notify ICO within 72 hours if there's a personal data breach

  9. Sample Ticketing Privacy Notice (summary) — insert on ticketing platform

    We collect your name and email to provide tickets and send event information. We process your data as part of our contractual relations with you to deliver the event. We store your data securely, retain ticketing data for 7 years for audit purposes, and never share your data with third parties for marketing unless you provide explicit consent. To exercise any rights (access/delete), contact [Data Protection lead email].

  10. Vendor DPA checklist

  11. Ensure processor detail (sub-processors), security measures (encryption at rest/in transit), delete policy and breach notification clauses, UK/EU cross-border transfer compliance

  12. Sample DPA checklist / required clauses

  13. Processor details: list sub-processors, name/address, jurisdiction
  14. Purpose & scope: scope of processing and what data fields are shared
  15. Security: minimum security standards (encryption, MFA for access), audit rights
  16. Deletion/return: stipulate data deletion or return at contract end and minimum retention limits
  17. Data subject rights: how processor supports data subject access, rectification or deletion
  18. Sub-processors: permission/notification clause for further sub-processors
  19. Breach notification: timelines and support for breach response and forensic support

  20. Liability & indemnities: limitations of liability and responsibilities for data incidents

  21. Data breach incident procedure

  22. Contain and assess scope of breach; isolate affected systems
  23. Notify Data Protection Lead and any affected vendors
  24. Notify ICO within 72 hours if breach is likely to result in a risk to people's rights and freedoms
  25. Inform affected individuals where there is a high risk to their rights

Cross-Reference: See Appendix 13.22 for downloadable DPA sample clauses and detailed privacy notice wording.

docs.title: Appendix 13.24 — Action Plan for Legal Review (Priority List)
docs.text:
[GOVERNANCE NOTE: PROFESSIONAL INDEMNITY] You are not a lawyer. Do not draft your own contracts for high-risk activities. Cost Benefit: A £500 legal review now can save £50,000 in litigation later.

Use this short checklist to instruct solicitors and specialist counsel on priority items to review before any contract or high-value decision is executed. - APA/Asset Protection Agreement (Network Rail / TfL): Review for conditions, liability and fee structure. - DPA & ticketing processor agreements: Ensure appropriate security, breach process and deletion/retention policy. - MoU with landowner: Check for any hidden covenants or liabilities on the title. - Insurances: Confirm levels and types of required insurance for contractors and volunteers. - Trade contracts for high-value suppliers: standard T&Cs and performance KPIs.

Value Engineering: Process of reviewing design to reduce costs without compromising essential function or safety; distinct from corner-cutting.

Wayfinding: Design of signage, landmarks, and spatial cues helping people navigate environment; critical for promenade theatre where audience moves through space.

docs.text:
[GOVERNANCE NOTE: REALISM] Statutory bodies do not care about your opening night. Planning and Asset Protection timelines are fixed. You must fit your artistic programme around them, not vice versa.

Sample milestone order (adjust on site specifics) 1. Discovery complete (landowner contact, surveys, pre-app) — no works 2. Pre-planning engagement and statutory consultations (including Network Rail / TfL) — enables planning submission 3. docs.title: Procurement, Commitments and Contracting Triggers
docs.text:
• Do not place irrevocable orders for critical temporary works and structural kit until Building Control approval and Asset Protection Agreement are in place.
  • For high-value items (>£25k) or long-lead-time equipment (scaffold, piled foundations), condition orders on receipt of formal permissions and a signed APA if works affect track works.
  • Avoid prefunding or pre-purchasing more than 40% of kit value before final planning sign-off, unless you have specific pre-approved variation controls and a funding buffer.
  • Use short lead-time 'option to buy' or supplier hold agreements where possible to reserve availability without committing funds prematurely.

docs.title: When to Prioritise Partnerships
docs.text:
• Include partnerships from the earliest Discovery phase: funders and local stakeholders will judge the project favourably if partnerships are demonstrably embedded into the delivery model.

Types of collaborations and practical uses 1. Venue & Landowner Partnerships (TfL / Network Rail / Private Landlords) - Why: land access, permissions, shared maintenance, and long-term land-use relationships. - Practical value: reduced licence fees, joint PR, assistance with local stakeholders, help with access and coordination. - What to ask: clarity on access times, asset protection constraints, liability, site restoration expectations (see Appendix 13.10 Handback Checklist).

  1. Local Business Partnerships (cafés, pubs, market vendors)
  2. Why: operational support, in-kind services, cross-marketing and ticketing partnerships.
  3. Practical value: in-kind supplies, discounted catering, volunteer recruitment, advertising in local venues.

  4. Example offer: a mutually beneficial discount (e.g., 10% discount for patrons who show the event ticket) or in-kind sponsorship in return for visibility.

  5. Community & Culture Partnerships (community centres, schools, Rotherhithe community groups)

  6. Why: Reach, consultation, programming co-creation and community buy-in.
  7. Practical value: local volunteers, community content, shared events and trust-building.

  8. What to formalise: a simple MoU or co-programming agreement clarifying roles, small financial arrangements, safeguarding expectations, and reciprocity.

  9. Service Providers (e.g., Local Trades, H&S Consultants, Acoustics, Security, Box Office providers)

  10. Why: operational capability, specialist skill transfer, often quicker or cheaper than bringing external teams from farther afield.

  11. Practical value: improved procurement times, local knowledge, flexibility around site constraints.

  12. Statutory & Non-statutory Partners (Southwark Council, TfL, Network Rail, Police)

  13. Why: approvals, supportive services, enforcement, and operational liaison for public safety.
  14. Practical value: smoother planning, quicker resolution of constraints, and essential safety oversight on rail-adjacent sites.

Partnership formation steps (pragmatic, standard process) 1) Discovery: map potential partners and value they could bring. Use a short spreadsheet with value categories (in-kind / financial / service / marketing). 2) Approach: prepare a two-paragraph approach message and an MoU template. Offer clear benefits to partners (e.g., 'co-created family event on 21-25 Jul, 2 hours per day, expected footfall 1,000'). 3) Negotiate: clarify expectations, data sharing obligations, insurance, safeguarding and liability. 4) Formalise: sign a short MoU or SLA, depending on the complexity. Keep it simple for small partnerships; formal contracts for higher-value or ongoing support. 5) Activate: include partners in key pre-event briefings and coordination meetings; provide clear lines for communication during events.

Sample MoU clauses (non-legal, high level) - Purpose: "[Name] will provide X in-kind and Y services; the venue operator will provide Y visibility and Z access in return." - Duration: Scale and start/end dates. - Liability: Each party maintains insurance and will not hold the other liable for negligence. - Safeguarding: where relevant, partner confirms DBS checks and safeguarding practices for staff/volunteers. - Termination: Simple clause allowing termination for cause with 30 days’ notice.

Partnership management & maintenance - Assign a named Partnership Lead (Producer/Community Lead) with a single contact for each partner. - Monthly partner updates in the delivery phase (email) and a pre-event coordination call 2–3 weeks prior to opening. - Review partner performance and community impact post-project (Appendix 13.17 evaluation template).

Measuring partnership value (practical metrics) - In-kind value: estimate retail value for donated goods and services (e.g., catering, furniture, staging). - Volunteer value: volunteer hours × local living wage rate for equivalent staff time. - Marketing reach: estimated audience exposure (local footfall, social media reach; use simple percentage multipliers). - Equity outcomes: number of local participants, number of local suppliers used.

Local procurement guidance - Prioritise local SMEs where practical: write procurement sections with 'Buy Local' guidance for small items; record preferred supplier lists. - Use proportionate contracting: use simple POs for small purchases; consider multiple quotes for items >£10k. - Social value in procurement: include clauses that prioritize local job opportunities and environmental performance where practical.

Pitfalls and mitigations - Misaligned expectations: set clear objectives and budgets; use the sample MoU to clarify deliverables. - Reputation risk: vet partners for community standing and service delivery. - Safeguarding & legal gaps: ensure any partner involved with children and vulnerable adults complies with safeguarding checks and DBS requirements.

docs.title: Appendix 13.17 — Post-Project Evaluation Template
docs.text:
[GOVERNANCE NOTE: INSTITUTIONAL MEMORY] A project without an evaluation is a wasted learning opportunity. Do not hide failures. Funders respect honest analysis of what went wrong more than a "glossy" report that claims perfection. Key Principle: Evaluate against original aims, not just final outcomes.

  1. Executive Summary (Key outcomes vs planned)
  2. Performance against objectives: community engagement, audience numbers, financials
  3. Health & Safety: incidents, near-misses, improvements made
  4. Environmental & site restoration outcomes (before/after photos, utility close-offs)
  5. Financial reconciliation and explanations of key variances
  6. Lessons learned and recommendations for future projects
  7. Archive and handover materials (where stored, who is responsible)

docs.title: Appendix 13.20 — Procurement & Tender Evaluation Checklist (Short)
docs.text:
[GOVERNANCE NOTE: PUBLIC MONEY] Procurement is about defensibility, not just price. If you are spending grant money, you must be able to prove you achieved value for money. Audit Trail: Keep every quote, email, and decision log. You may be audited 5 years from now.

  1. Procurement policy and small-works approach
  2. For small orders (<£10k): 1-2 quotes preferred; public sector orgs may require 3 quotes for transparency.
  3. For works between £10k–£75k: gather 3 written quotes and ensure contractor competence checks (insurance, references, H&S records).

  4. For >£75k: tender process with written selection criteria, PSQs and interview where appropriate.

  5. Tender evaluation matrix

  6. Include criteria such as: Cost (40%), Experience & References (25%), H&S & Competence (15%), Social & Local Value (10%), Delivery Timescale (10%).

  7. Use a simple scoring out of 10 per criterion; multiply by weight to produce overall score.

  8. Minimum pre-qualification checklist

  9. Insurance (Public Liability ≥ £5m), Employer’s Liability, Works-specific certification, CSCS for staff, DBS where appropriate, references, and evidence of craft competence.

  10. Local supplier development

  11. Where local capacity is limited, consider bundling smaller suppliers into a single contract or using an aggregator.

Please note: Any legal or procurement template included in this manual must be reviewed by the organisation's legal counsel before use; the MoU and sample clauses are illustrative only.

docs.title: 13.5 Risk Assessment Framework & Register Template
docs.text:
[GOVERNANCE NOTE: PROJECT INTELLIGENCE] Risk assessment isn't bureaucratic box-ticking—it's your project intelligence system. A well-maintained risk register identifies threats early (when they're cheap to mitigate). Board Assurance: The Board should review the top 5 risks at every meeting.

Strategic Purpose: Risk Management as Project Intelligence

Risk assessment isn't bureaucratic box-ticking—it's your project intelligence system. A well-maintained risk register identifies threats early (when they're cheap to mitigate), tracks emerging issues, and provides evidence of due diligence for funders, insurers, and the board.

The Golden Thread: Risks identified in Discovery inform design decisions in Implementation and operational procedures during performance runs. Your risk register is a living document that evolves with the project.

Legal Context: - CDM Regulations 2015: Require risk assessment during design and construction - Health and Safety at Work Act 1974: Employer duty to assess workplace risks - Management of Health and Safety at Work Regulations 1999: Mandate written risk assessments for 5+ employees

When to Use: - Discovery Phase: Initial risk identification and site hazard assessment - Implementation Phase: Update as design develops and construction begins - Operations: Daily/weekly review; immediate update after incidents - Closure Phase: Final review and lessons learned documentation

docs.title: Risk Assessment Methodology
docs.text:
Step 1: Identify Hazards

Systematically identify anything that could cause harm: - Physical hazards: Railway proximity, working at height, confined spaces, utilities - Environmental hazards: Weather, flooding, ground conditions, noise - Operational hazards: Crowd management, fire, power failure, structural failure - Health hazards: Dust, fumes, manual handling, stress - Security hazards: Trespass, theft, vandalism, terrorism - Reputational hazards: Negative media, community opposition, funder withdrawal

Step 2: Assess Likelihood and Impact

Likelihood (L) Description Probability 1 - Very Unlikely Has never happened; extremely rare circumstances required <5% 2 - Unlikely Could happen but uncommon; specific circumstances required 5-25% 3 - Possible Might happen; has occurred elsewhere in similar contexts 25-50% 4 - Likely Will probably happen; common occurrence in this type of project 50-75% 5 - Very Likely Expected to happen; almost certain without mitigation >75% Impact (I) Description Consequence 1 - Negligible Minor inconvenience; no injury; <£500 cost Easily absorbed 2 - Minor First aid injury; minor delay; £500-£5k cost Manageable within contingency 3 - Moderate Medical treatment injury; significant delay; £5k-£20k cost Requires senior management action 4 - Major Serious injury; major delay/cancellation; £20k-£100k cost Threatens project viability 5 - Catastrophic Fatality; project failure; >£100k cost; permanent reputation damage Project-ending consequence

Risk Score = Likelihood × Impact

Score Range Risk Level Response 1-5 🟢 Low Monitor; accept risk; standard controls adequate 6-12 🟡 Medium Active management; mitigation plan required; regular review 13-25 🔴 High Urgent action; senior management oversight; may be project-critical

docs.text: Strategy When to Use Example Avoid Risk too high; eliminate activity Don't build within 3m of live railway if APA impossible Reduce Implement controls to lower likelihood or impact Install 2.4m fence + CCTV to reduce trespass likelihood Transfer Share risk with third party (insurance, contract) Professional indemnity insurance for designer errors Accept Risk low enough to tolerate; monitor only Accept minor weather-related delays as normal

docs.title: Risk Register Maintenance
docs.text:
Discovery Phase: - Initial assessment by H&S consultant and project team - Site walkover to identify physical hazards - Stakeholder interviews (identify reputational/relationship risks) - Review every 2 weeks; update as surveys/reports received

Implementation Phase: - Principal Designer adds construction-specific risks - Principal Contractor owns site safety risks - Producer monitors schedule/budget/relationship risks - Review weekly at project meetings - Update immediately after any incident or near-miss

Operations (Performance Run): - Site Manager completes daily review (new risks? controls working?) - Producer reviews weekly - Board briefed monthly with top 5 risks - Immediate escalation for any high-risk events

Closure Phase: - Final review captures lessons learned - Document "what worked" and "what we'd do differently" - Archive for future projects
